correct.text: People typically jump to solutions when asked this question. It may be tempting to jump to specific ideas but the Jobs to be Done framework gets us to take a step back and think about the fundamental tasks customers are try to get done in their lives. When people buy ice cream, what Jobs are they looking to fulfill beyond enjoying something tasty? The next few questions will guide us through the Jobs Atlas.

questions.prompt: You're the owner of a popular local company that makes delicious ice cream. You want to expand your business. What should you do in order to attract more customers and expand your sales?

answers: Cooling off on a hot day
A pick-me-up after a tough day at work or school

correct.text: There's nothing quite like eating ice cream on a hot summer day to cool off. Getting ice cream is also a great way to extend a date that's going well or hang out longer with a friend to finish that engaging conversation. Those are just a couple functional jobs that ice cream can satisfy. Eating ice cream after a tough day is more of an emotional, rather than functional job. And sprinkles, sweetness, and coldness are product features rather than jobs. Remember that we're trying to avoid solutions and features and focusing on the needs of the customer first.

questions.prompt: The first part of the Jobs to be Done Atlas is to identify the job. Jobs can fulfill functional and emotional needs. Which of the following is a functional job addressed by ice cream?

answers: Doing a bunch of dishes Saturday night after a 12-person party
dropping ice cream onto the pavement while strolling around town
eating too much from the tub while watching a horror movie

correct.text: As you might have guessed, all these are specific contexts in which people run into some pain points. Whether it's doing the dishes, dripping and dropping ice cream, or just overeating, you can learn about different customer issues as they use your product in different current approaches.

questions.prompt: The next step is to determine the current approaches that people are adopting in order to see which pain points are experienced. Which of the following are pain points caused by current approaches to eating ice cream?

correct.text: While low-calorie, sugar-free, and small-portions are important success criteria for some people (think about the success of Halo Top ice cream), in this case, having an ice cream that doesn't melt all over your hand while you stroll around town in the summer seems to be the most important success criterion. The longer it lasts on a summer day, the longer it can keep you cool.

questions.prompt: Success criteria are indications of whether a job has been fulfilled, though they are not jobs themselves. Thinking back to the job of cooling off on a hot summer day, which of the following success criteria seem most relevant for your ice cream?

answers: The ice cream is very expensive
It's difficult to find your ice cream at the local store
The ice cream's consistency is too soft
The carton's design looks too generic

correct.text: If someone doesn't like the consistency of the ice cream after trying it out, it's likely they won't buy it again. The other options (price, availability, and visual appeal) can be obstacles to adoption and may prevent people from purchasing your product in the first place.

questions.prompt: Next up in the Jobs Atlas is identifying obstacles. Obstacles come in two forms: obstacles to adoption and obstacles to use. Obstacles to adoption are hurdles that limit a consumer's willingness to buy an offering. Obstacle to use are hurdles limiting the likelihood of continued use. Which one of the following is an obstacle to use?

answers: Customers would pay 30% more per serving if it has fewer calories but feels more filling
The global ice cream market is projected to be $69.3 billion USD in 2022
It costs you about $3 in ingredients to make a gallon of ice cream
Organic and low-fat are the fastest growing areas in ice cream

correct.text: If customers are willing to pay 30% more for less calories and a more filling ice cream, that's an insight into the value of a specific customer jobs. The other options: market sizing, production cost, and market trends can also be helpful but aren't jobs-rooted. Measuring value is tricky so a value-based pricing strategy accounting for unique and emotional jobs can help you uncover how expensive the solution can and should be.

questions.prompt: Next up is determining value, or trying to understand how much money is at stake with respect to a new solution. Markets need to be framed in terms of jobs, rather than products themselves. Which of the following statements reflects Jobs to be Done thinking regarding value?

answers: extra TV time for the kids

correct.text: A broader view of what constitutes competition can illuminate more avenues for growth. Your ice cream isn't just competing against other brands of ice cream. Beyond your traditional or direct competitors, your offering also competes against other goods and services that satisfy the same jobs.

questions.prompt: The last step in the Atlas is to identify the competition. Who are you really competing against, in addition to other ice creams? What other things can satisfy the jobs that your ice cream does?

title: How well do you know Jobs to be Done?
